entry.content:
Ok. So today was (is) my birthday, and I've been dealing with a few quarter-life-crises. Objectively considered my life is in a good place, which I find is useful to reflect upon, especially when you become self-centered. Gratefulness is key.

Thank you, to everyone. Every. Single. One. Some have been there during my emotional phases, my near mental breakdowns and everything in between. Without each and every influence I would not be the person I am today (riding the train to horizon of obvious here)

Anyhow, I decided to bake brownies again! This time I've tweaked a bit more at the recipe, and in the future, I hope to make a completely vegan and gluten-free brownie. Shout out to Yana for reminding me that some are actually gluten intolerant; not sure if she is though.

As you'll soon see, most of the recipe remains unchanged. These brownies are fudgy when cold, and slightly !moist! when at room temperature. In the fridge they can keep for at least 2 weeks, probably longer.

As cake flour contains less protein than white bread flour, you'll find that these brownies are slightly softer and have a more pleasant texture than the 2.0 iteration.

Ingredients

  • 1/2 cup cake flour (71g)
  • 1/2 cup white bread flour (71g)
  • (I always baked with pure white bread flour, as it increased chewiness)
  • 1 tsp salt (5g)
  • 2 tbsp cacao powder (15g)
  • 3x80g dark semi-sweet chocolate bars (I used the Nestlé Albany brand)
  • TIP Replace one of the above bars with a peppermint crisp bar
  • 2 tsp instant coffee (Nescafe classic or Jacobs) (optional)
  • 1 cup of butter (227g, salted is fine)
  • 1 cup of treacle sugar (about 150-160g)
  • 5 eggs, at room temperature
  • 2 tsp vanilla extract (10g)

Notes

  • This recipe makes 24 brownies (cut them 6 by 4)
  • You will be mixing the dry ingredients into the bowl of wet ingredients later on in this recipe.
  • Do not use your oven's convection fan
  • Our oven only has a top-element, but it does have top and bottom heat setting, which I used.
  • If your oven heats unevenly you should turn the tray around in the middle of the bake

Utensils

  • A medium sized pot for preparing the chocolate
  • A mixing bowl for the dry mixture
  • Baking tray (9x13 inch 22x33cm) glass is best, but metal is also fine. A metal pan will bake faster (25 minutes) whereas glass will take around 30 minutes.
  • Kitchen fork or tablespoon for stirring melted chocolate

Oven & Baking Tray prep

You can do these after the whole batter is completed, as there is a resting time before starting baking. 1. Preheat the oven to 180 C and use the central tray. 2. Oil / butter / Spray-'n-Cook your baking tray

Dry mix

  • Mix the following together
  • Cacao powder
  • Salt
  • Flour

Wet mix

You can alternatively use a pot on low heat to melt the butter, chocolate and sugar instead of

  1. Break chocolate bars into single blocks, while inside their packet if possible.
  2. Cut butter into smaller pieces and place in your pot, then turn it up to a low heat. The butter MUST NOT sizzle, it must merely melt. Stir occasionally.
  3. Add the Chocolate bars and coffee to your pot, stirring to melt and to prevent it from burning to the bottom. If your stove is really hot then occasionally remove the pot from the stove.
  4. Stir the treacle sugar into the chocolate sauce until mostly dissolved. You might find that the batter feels sandy from the sugar. This is normal.
  5. Remove the pot from the heat and let it cool for at least 20 minutes, stirring the batter every 10 minutes to prevent clumps from forming. NOTE trust me on this, otherwise you'll be eating scrambled egg later.
  6. When cooled, add the vanilla extract.
  7. Whisk in 3 eggs till combined, then add the 2 remaining eggs and whisk until combined.
  8. Slowly add the dry mix to the bowl while folding it into the mixture using a spoon or rubber spatula.
  9. Pour the batter into your baking tray and smooth it out
  10. Let the mix stand for 10 minutes so that any bubbles rise to the top.
  11. Move oven rack to the middle position.
  12. Bake in the oven for 20 minutes, then checking every 1 minute, till a toothpick put into the centre of the pan comes out with only a few moist crumbs sticking to it.

Post Baking

  1. Cover the baking pan with a clean dish cloth and let it stand for 10 minutes.
  2. Loosen the brownies from the base of the tray
  3. On a clean surface, turn the tray over, leaving the brownies covered for a further 10 minutes.
  4. Cut into the appropriate shape (6x4 for the suggested 24 brownies)

References

  • This recipe was adapted from Browneyed Baker's brownie recipe.
  • Take a look at my previous iteration for ideas on what you can experiment with.

Ingredients

  • 1 cup (142 grams) of white bread flour
  • 1 tsp salt
  • 2 tbsp cacao powder

  • 1 cup of brown sugar

  • 2 tsp vanilla extract

Notes

  • This recipe makes 24 brownies (cut them 6 by 4)
  • You will be mixing the dry ingredients into the bowl of wet ingredients later on in this recipe.
  • Do not use your oven's convection fan
  • Our oven only has a top-element, but it does have top and bottom heat setting, which I used.

Utensils

  • A heat-proof bowl for the batter, (stainless steel or glass), used for melting over the saucepan
  • A bowl for the dry mixture
  • Baking tray (9x13 inch 22x33cm) glass is best, but metal is also fine. A metal pan will bake faster (25 minutes) whereas glass will take around 30 minutes.
  • Saucepan
  • Kitchen fork or tablespoon for stirring melted chocolate

Dry mix

  • Mix the following together
  • Cacao powder
  • Salt
  • Flour

Wet mix

  1. Bring water to a simmer in a saucepan
  2. Break chocolate bars into single blocks, while inside their packet if possible.
  3. Next, cut your butter into smaller pieces and add the
  4. Chocolate bars
  5. Butter, and
  6. Coffee to your heat-proof bowl.
  7. Place the bowl over the saucepan. Continue to stir till smooth, then turn the stove off.
  8. Slowly add the brown sugar while mixing it into the chocolate sauce.
  9. Stir in until mostly dissolved, there were definitely still some granules left in mine.
  10. Remove the bowl from the pan and let it stand for 15 minutes, stirring every 5 minutes, till it reaches room temperature.
  11. Add the vanilla extract.
  12. Whisk in 3 eggs till combined, then add the 2 remaining eggs and whisk until combined.
  13. Slowly add the dry mix to the bowl while folding it into the mixture using a spoon or rubber spatula.
  14. Pour the batter into your baking tray and smooth it out
  15. Let the mix stand for 10 minutes so that any bubbles raise to the top.
  16. Move oven rack to the middle position.
  17. Bake in the oven for 20 minutes, then checking every 1 minute, till a toothpick put into the centre of the pan comes out with only a few moist crumbs sticking to it.

Post Baking

  1. Cover the baking pan with a clean dish cloth and let it stand for 10 minutes.
  2. Loosen the brownies from the base of the tray
  3. On a clean surface, turn the tray over, leaving the brownies covered for a further 10 minutes.
  4. Cut into the appropriate shape (6x4 for the suggested 24 brownies)
  5. Keeps for 3 days at room temperature or longer when kept in the refrigerator.

This recipe was adapted from Browneyed Baker's brownie recipe.

entry.content:
These brownies are fudgy, and absolutely delicious. I have cut back on the sugar in the original recipe, and it produced a lovely, not-too-sweet brownie. Will definitely be making these again!

Ingredients

  • 1 1/4 cups (177 grams) of all-purpose-flour (I used white bread flour, and it turned out great)
  • 1 tsp salt
  • 2 tbsp cacao powder
  • 3x80g dark chocolate bars (I used the Nestlé Albany brand)
  • 1.5 tsp instant coffee (Nescafe classic or Jacobs) (optional)
  • 1 cup (227g) of butter
  • 1 - 1.5 cups of brown sugar
  • 5 eggs, at room temperature
  • 2 tsp vanilla extract

Instructions

  • You'll be mixing the dry ingredients into the bowl of wet ingredients later on in this recipe.
  • This recipe makes 24 brownies (cut them 6 by 4)

Utensils

  • Tablespoon or large spoon for stirring melted chocolate
  • Saucepan
  • Baking tray (9x13 inch 22x33cm) glass is best, but metal is also fine
  • One heat-proof bowl for the batter (melting over the saucepan)
  • One bowl for the dry mix

Oven & Baking Tray

  1. Preheat the oven to 180 C
  2. Oil / butter your baking tray

Dry mix

  • Mix the following together
  • Cacao powder
  • Salt
  • Flour

Wet mix

  1. Bring water to a simmer in a saucepan
  2. Add the following to your other bowl
  3. Chocolate bars
  4. Butter, and
  5. Coffee
  6. Stir until smooth, then turn off the stove
  7. Add the sugar to the chocolate mixture
  8. Stir in until dissolved or it doesn't dissolve anymore
  9. Remove the bowl from the pan and let it stand till it's at room temperature
  10. Add vanilla extract
  11. Whisk in 3 eggs till combined, then add the 2 remaining eggs and whisk until combined.
  12. Slowly add the dry mix to the bowl while folding it into the mixture using a spoon or rubber spatula.
  13. Pour the batter into your baking tray and smooth it out
  14. Bake in the oven for about 30 minutes, till a toothpick put into the centre of the pan comes out with only a few moist crumbs sticking to it.

Post Balking

  1. Cover the baking pan with a clean dish cloth and let it stand for 15 minutes.
  2. Loosen the brownie from the base of the tray
  3. On a clean surface, turn the tray over, leaving the brownies covered for a further 15 minutes.
  4. Cut into the appropriate shape (6x4 for the suggested 24 brownies)
  5. Keeps for 3 days at room temperature or longer when kept in the refrigerator.

References

This recipe was adapted from Browneyed Baker's brownie recipe.

entry.content:
Ingredients

  • 4 tbsp chick pea water (brine), this replaces the egg of normal mayo
  • 1 tbsp lemon juice
  • 1/4 - 1/2 tsp salt (or more to taste)
  • 1 - 2 tsp of whole grain mustard
  • 250ml of flavour neutral oil: canola, flax seed or a mixture of these with sunflower (not olive oil)

Equipment

  • stick blender
  • a mixing bowl/container that is only slightly broader than your stick blender, this prevents splattering and ensures that the oil will cover the blender blade.

Instructions

  • Add all ingredients except the oil to a mixing bowl
  • Have someone slowly add the oil while you blend the mixture without stopping.

You will find that that the mayo does not take till a critical point is reached: right after the blade is completely submersed in oil.

  • You can move the blender stick in an upright stirring fashion, with some up and down motion. The up-down motion takes precedence when the mixture begins to thicken.

Fixing a Runny Mess

  • If your mayo stays runny, then you may have: added the oil too quickly, used stale chick pea water, or made a mistake while blending. All is not lost, however!

If a batch fails or comes out runny, you can still save it by preparing another correctly. As the second batch begins to thicken, slowly pour the failed mixture in while thoroughly blending it.

Tips

  • You can make plain mayo mixture without the mustard seed, as far as I could tell only the chick pea water (and maybe 1/2 tbsp of lemon juice) is really necessary to get the mayo to thicken.
  • You can use the chickpeas to make a yummy hummus

entry.content:
Recently I've been trying my hand at baking bread. Here is a slightly adapted recipe taken from a post by Bridget Oland.

Ingredients

  • 2 cups boiling water
  • 1 cup rolled oats
    • BEST Large Jungle oats (rolled)
    • OK Normal Jungle oats (quick oats)
    • NO Instant Jungle oats (well, instant)
    • Look here for images.
  • 2 Tbsp butter (replace with margarine for a Vegan alternative)
  • 3 tsp salt
  • 1 cup warm water
  • 20g dry yeast powder
  • 2 tsp sugar
  • 2/3 cup (220g/167ml) or (150ml if you like it less sweet) of molasses
  • 7 cups of flour
  • 3 Unsifted (stone ground) whole wheat flour
  • 4 Whole Wheat brown bread flour

Preparation

  • In a large bowl (you'll be making the dough in it later) mix the oats, butter and salt with the 2 cups of boiling water
  • Let stand till the mixture has become lukewarm.

Activate the yeast

  • After the oats has cooled,
  • use a second bowl and dissolve sugar in 1 cup lukewarm water,
  • add the yeast and mix thoroughly,
  • let it stand for about a minute or two
  • then mix it evenly into the cooled oats mixture.
  • Now stir in the molasses till dissolved.

Oil the pans

  • Sufficiently oil the bread pan(s).
  • You may need two if your pans are small.

Putting it all together

  • Begin adding your whole wheat flour to the mixture,
  • continue mixing till all of it has been added.
  • Next start adding your brown bread flour.
  • I've found that the dough remained far too sticky to knead, so instead continue stirring the mixture, moving what is on the outside of the mixture to the centre for 5-10 minutes.

Let it sit

  • Place the dough into baking trays,
  • let it rise in a warm place for 1:30 - 2:00 hours, or till about doubled in size.

Bake it

  • 5 minutes before baking, heat oven to 180C (350F).
  • Bake for around 30-45 minutes.

Finishing touches

  • Turn the loaf (still in its tray) on one side, covering the top with a clean dish cloth.
  • let stand for 10 minutes, then
  • turn it on the other side and repeat.
  • Remove from tray and let it cool.

Meal pairing

This bread goes really well with veggie soups.

entry.content:
Ingredients

Dry

  • 3 cups self-raising flour
  • 1 cup of sugar
  • 1 cup of cocoa powder
  • 2 tsp baking soda
  • 3 pinches of salt
  • 3 80g slabs of chocolate (alternatively melted and mixed with wet batter)

Wet

  • 1 cup of milk
  • 1 cup of vegetable oil
  • 500g plain double cream yoghurt ~ 2 cups
  • 2 eggs
  • 1 teaspoon of vanilla extract

Instructions

  • preheat oven to 180C (~350F)
  • use a food processor or grater to make the chocolate fine. Most of it should be very, but if a few are chunky that's also ok.
  • Alternatively, melt and blend into the wet ingredients
  • Mix all the dry ingredients thoroughly
  • Mix all the wet ingredients thoroughly, separately from the dry ingredients
  • Add wet batter to the dry ingredients, and mix till smooth
  • spray baking tray with non-stick spray or smear with oil / butter
  • pour batter into baking tray
  • bake for 40min, use a fork to test if it's ready.
  • Remove from the oven and cover cake for 5-10 minutes to keep it from drying out (if you're adding sauce it shouldn't be a problem).

Toppings (Optional)

Chocolate Sauce

This sauce is still experimental. There are quite a few ways to prepare it, this is one way. You can change the quantities to suit your taste.

Ingredients

  • 400ml milk
  • 1 cup of hot chocolate
  • 1/4 cup of sugar (optional)

Instructions

  • simmer for around 20-30 minutes, stirring continuously (4-5 on a 6 scale stove top).
  • or 10 minutes on 50% heat in the microwave
  • The sauce won't really thicken, but should taste chocolatey, and not too sweet.
  • When the cake is done baking, make tiny holes in the surface with fork then
  • pour sauce over the cake, making sure it doesn't get soggy. Stop before it does!
  • If any sauce remains, keep it for later when you eat the cake

Caramel treat

As an alternative to the chocolate sauce, spread some caramel treat on the cake after it has cooled down.

The finishing touches

  • let it cool for 20-30 minutes before serving
